results.title: In the mind of the architect: ep. 3 : corrugated dream
results.creator_credit: Janne Ryan, Tim Clark and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Part three of a three-part television documentary series about architecture and the way we interact with it. The series focuses on the work of a number of Australian architects with diverse styles and philosophies. Through interviews with these architects and the people that occupy the houses and public buildings they have designed, it investigates the passions, politics and creative vision that shape the final appearance of public and private spaces. Part three ‘Corrugated Dreams’, asks if there is a style of architecture that can be described as identifiably Australian. It looks at the work of architects like Harry Seidler and Glenn Murcutt which has often been regarded as conveying an Australian sensibility, as well that of architects who have reacted against the notion of an Australian style. Striking cinematography by Matt Temple brings the many examples of contemporary Australian architecture shown to life. With music by ‘The Necks’ and narration by David Wenham. An accompanying multimedia presentation to the series that features virtual tours of cutting-edge Australian architecture, transcripts and audio-visual slide show highlights of the programs can be found at: http://www.abc.net.au/architecture/default.html

results.title: In the mind of the architect : ep. 2: the public good
results.creator_credit: Janne Ryan, Tim Clark and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Part two of a three-part television documentary series about architecture and the way we interact with it. The series focuses on the work of a number of Australian architects with diverse styles and philosophies. Through interviews with these architects and the people that occupy the houses and public buildings they have designed, it investigates the passions, politics and creative vision that shape the final appearance of public and private spaces. Part two ‘The Public Good’, looks at the forces at work behind the realisation of public spaces and buildings in our cities. It features the work of the firm Denton/Corker/Marshall who designed the Citylink gateway in Melbourne, and focuses on the controversies surrounding the East Circular Quay building on Sydney’s foreshore, and Federation Square in Melbourne. Striking cinematography by Matt Temple brings the many examples of contemporary Australian architecture shown to life. With music by ‘The Necks’ and narration by David Wenham. An accompanying multimedia presentation to the series that features virtual tours of cutting-edge Australian architecture, transcripts and audio-visual slide show highlights of the programs can be found at: http://www.abc.net.au/architecture/default.html

results.title: In the mind of the architect : ep. 1 : keeping the faith
results.creator_credit: Janne Ryan, Tim Clark and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Part one of a three-part television documentary series about architecture and the way we interact with it. The series focuses on the work of a number of Australian architects with diverse styles and philosophies. Through interviews with these architects and the people that occupy the houses and public buildings they have designed, the series investigates the passions, politics and creative vision that shape the final appearance of public and private spaces. Part one ‘Keeping the Faith’ focuses on the legacy of modernist architecture in Australia. Buildings featured include the Commonwealth Law Courts and Storey Hall in Melbourne, and private residences designed by Sean Godsell. Striking cinematography by Matt Temple brings these and many other examples of contemporary Australian architecture to life. With music by ‘The Necks’ and narration by David Wenham. An accompanying multimedia presentation to the series that features virtual tours of cutting-edge Australian architecture, transcripts and audio-visual slide show highlights of the programs can be found at: http://www.abc.net.au/architecture/default.html

results.title: In the mind of a murderer Pt.1
results.brief_description: The first part of a documentary that examines the case of the “Hillside Strangler”. The search, by police, to track down the strangler is covered and interviews with police, psychologists and lawyers are included. The suspected culprit is believed to suffer from a multiple personalities disorder and this issue is discussed by the experts.

results.title: In the mind of a murderer Pt .2
results.brief_description: This is the second part of a documentary that examines the case of the “Hillside Strangler”. The program focuses on the debate over the psychological state of the suspected culprit who appears to suffer from a multiple personalities disorder. Interviews with the man’s friends, workmates and wife are included, and leading mental health experts comment.

results.title: In the lap of the gods
results.brief_description: All Greece’s wonders lie ‘in the lap of the gods’ - the birthplace of European civilisation. Here are the magnificent remains of a bygone era where all the splendour and glory of the past comes to life. Beginning with the fairy-tale Palace of Knossos on the Island of Crete, through the famous Delphi Sanctuary, with its celebrated oracle, and the majesty and serenity of Olympia, to the heights of Athens’ Acropolis, we come to understand the search for the perfection of the body and the soul that was the glory of Greece.

results.title: In the footsteps of the pharaohs
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Grainger Television Australia
results.brief_description: Producer and presenter Greg Grainger embarks on a journey into the ancient civilization of Egypt’s past, as well as the vibrancy of modern Egypt. He begins his journey at Abu Simbel near the Sudanese border, sails across dams in Aswan, along the river Nile to Luxor, and in Cairo explores new excavations around the pyramids. Along the way he encounters boatmen, bellydancers, feasts, markets, bazaars, and wedding festivities. The sights and sounds are a lasting legacy of an amazing ancient culture.

results.title: In the family
results.brief_description: A compelling documentary in which eight women and two men, all adult survivors of child sex abuse, talk about how that experience has affected their lives. Each has their own intimate story to tell and they reveal personal anguish, guilt and recriminations experienced. This documentary looks at the memory process involved for many people who have repressed memories of their abuse and the long term ramifications of that abuse including sexual problems and revictimisations.

results.title: In the desert we have written our names
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Barnes, Don Keyes and Headquarters Training Command
results.brief_description: This story traces the history of the Australian Light Horse from it’s inception during the Boer War through to the end of the Great War. Presented by Mark Lee using film footage from the Australian War Memorial, extracts from “Forty Thousand Horsemen”, soldiers diaries such as Ion L Iddriess, letters from Major Gen.Sir Henry George Chauvel, Djemal Pasha the Turkish Commander and letters and photos from the estate of Alice Chisholm an Australian woman who ran a Soldiers Club during the Middle East Campaign. It is a story of the men, their famous Waler horses and their great commander Harry Chauvel. Part 1: Saving the Suez - explains why, where and how the Light Horse came into being, their battlefields in the Boer War, World War I at Gallipoli and the beginning of the campaigns in the Middle East. Considered undisciplined by the English High Command because the men “refused to salute anyone they didn’t respect” while their Australian Officers appealed to their common sense and so formed an Espirit de Corp. Part 2: A Dash through the desert - takes over the story of the Light Horse stopping the Turks at the Suez canal and then beginning the offensive by taking the following towns- Kantarra, El Arish, Magdhaba, Rafa, Gaza, Beersheba, then onto Damascus and Jerusalem. They fought the Turks with gallantry, pride and determination yet retained respect for their enemy. “A trooper’s first duty is to his horse, then his equipment”, of the 150,000 horses that went to War, only 1 returned. Most of the good ones went to the Indian Army and the rest were shot, this order was due to quarrantine regulations. Politics (both internal and external) influenced how the Australian Light Horse are immortalised into Australian history.
